At 21:03 25/06/2004, you wrote:
>Before I respond...good news...it's up and running!  All the fundamental
>components are operational, and I've kicked off a number of client processes
>to do the distributed fitness evaluation.  I'll let them run over the
>weekend (while I go play up in the mountains) and see if it makes any
>progress.  I anticipate some bugs to fix, but who knows, maybe I've killed
>enough of them to let it limp along? :)

Good!

> >From: Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...>
> >
> >Could you use float throughout instead of double?  That would reduce memory
> >bandwidth requirements...
>
>I could try it and see what kind of difference it makes.  But this is a
>mathematical model domain, not a controller, so the added accuracy may
>actually be beneficial in the long run.  For a controller domain, I'd even
>consider using integers...

Float accuracy is about 6 sig figs, double is about 16 sig figs.

Your image data looks like it's 16bit, whcih is 5 sig figs.

>The output node is a summation node.  No sigmoid.  For a reason:  The output
>ranges need to be able to be more than +/-1.  So when I was first doing it,
>there were no sigmoids.  The sigmoids appear later as hidden nodes are
>added.

Surely you are normalizing your pixel values to a range of 0 - 1 or -1 to 1?

> >(if I may blow the trumpet for my inv-abs activation function here, it
> >should be more-stable w.r.t extreme numbers...)
>
>I know you've posted that before, but would you send it again so I have it
>for easy reference? :)

 >>>I was just playing with some equations, it's not easy to get the
 >>>right properties.  But how about x/(n+abs(x))?  That's a sigmoid, 
symmetric
 >>>about zero, equal to +1 at +infinity and -1 at -infinity.  n controls the
 >>>steepness and is equal to the x value where the curve reaches +0.5...


> >Other than that, the inside of activate will be more significant than the
> >detail of this loop.  Do you have an example of "activate" generated the
> >way you (currently) plan, and using network data of about the expected size
> >and connection density?
>
>Until the experiment gets well underway and the networks get larger, the
>activate functions are a bit small, but...
>
>run the following:
>
>wget http://www.hanlonsrazor.com:81/neat/iex/get_sample.cgi -O fitness.c
>
>That will pretend to be a client, fetch a fitness evaluation source file,
>and save it as fitness.c.

Yeah, I've looked at the file.  You're right, none of the functions are 
complex enough yet to really analyze for efficiency issues.

I do have a big question though: where's the input data.  e.g. all the 
functions I've seen so far only read left, right, top, bottom, none of them 
reference texels in the input image.  It could just be that none of them 
evolved to access a pixel yet, but I don't even see the data array in there.

e.g. I expected something like:

short Input[9][9] = { ... };

         Ian Badcoe
